title: Are the Japanese descended from Koreans? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, not exactly. The Japanese people are predominantly descendants of the ancient Yayoi people, while Koreans themselves formed from Siberians and local assimilated Yayoi (Peninsular Japonic). Today, we are undoubtedly closely related (besides that we are East Asians), but it is more complicated than it seems.   The ancient Yayoi people, also known as “Wajin”, originated in ancient southern or eastern China and migrated up north into the Korean Peninsula in about 1500 BC. (Below more about the genetics.) The ancient Mumun culture in the Korean peninsula as well as the Yayoi culture in Japan had Japonic speaking people. The Mumun/Yayoi culture originated in the Peninsula and has thus several distinct elements not found among other Yangtzean cultures. Nevertheless, rice-cultivation, and agriculture generally, played an important part. Later, proto-Koreanic tribes started migrating into the Peninsula from Manchuria, interacting with Japonic rice-agriculturalists and later assimilating them. It is suggested that vocabulary related to rice was borrowed from Japonic into Koreanic. The Japonic languages which were spoken in the Korean Peninsula are known as Peninsular Japonic. It is suggested that Baekje (and the Gaya confederation) was still Japonic speaking until it was conquered by proto-Koreans from Goguryeo. This event caused the large scale Yayoi migration into Japan. The Yayoi displaced the outnumbered Jōmon tribes. For this see as example: Out of Southern China?Proto-Japanese beyond the accent systemBayesian phylogenetic analysis supports an agricultural origin of Japonic languagesNortheast Asian Linguistic Ecology and the Advent of Rice Agriculture in Korea and JapanFrom Koguryo to Tamna: Slowly riding to the South with speakers of Proto-KoreanOn The Etymology of Middle Korean psʌr 'rice'Origins of the Japanese LanguageA History of the Korean LanguageReconstructing the Language Map of Prehistorical Northeast AsiaOn the Origins of the JapaneseThe terms Yayoi and Wajin can be used interchangeably. "Wajin" (和人) is also the ancient Chinese name for the Yamato people (Yamatai). There are two main theories about the origin of the Yayoi people: The most popular theory is that they were the people who brought wet rice cultivation to Japan from the Korean peninsula and Jiangnan, near the Yangtze River Delta in ancient China. This is supported by genetic and archeological researches and bones found in modern southeastern China.→ Proto-Japonic Yayoi migrated from Yangtze area to the Korean Peninsula 1500BC. There they developed the Mumun/Yayoi culture. They also formed tribal states (later known as “Jin state”) and the succeeding Samhan. After Proto-Koreans started expanding, the Yayoi started their expansion into Japan, replacing the Jōmon tribals. According to several historians, the Yayoi originated in the today Yunnan province in southern China. Suwa Haruo considered Wa-zoku (Wajin) to be part of the diverse Baiyue confederation (百越) along the Yangtze. The other theory is that Yayoi originated near the Liaoning area and got there into contact with northern Asian languages and people. There they adopted certain vocabulary related to spindle waving (which are also found in Koreanic and Tungusic). (The areal family Altaic, recently called Transeurasian, is because of language contact and long-term contact in this area.)Both theories are compatible.  The Japonic Yayoi/Mumun were present on large parts of the Korean Peninsula before they were displaced and assimilated by arriving proto-Koreans.   Japonic and Koreanic are unrelated and are more different in their proto form than today. There are only fewer than a dozen possible cognates, which may have been borrowed by Korean from Peninsular Japonic. Proposed cognates (Francis-Ratte 2016) turned out to be loanwords. Transeurasian theory (Robbeets) and her Japano-Koreanic cluster was dismissed by most linguists and recently criticized by two studies (Yurayong 2020 and Szeto 2020) as well as Kim et al. 2020 (rejecting Robbeets main part, the millet agriculture spread and hypothetical spindle waving vocabulary) and pointing out many inconsistencies. → Altaic/Transeurasian proposal is generally rejected and no new evidence was presented by the supporters. Here a recreation of Old-Japanese sound:https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=vZPHhRHVUco&t=79s Proto-Japonic is noted for many similarities to SEA languages, especially Austronesian languages. There are even several theories which try to link Japanese to Austronesian, but it remains controversial. There is typological evidence that Proto-Japonic may have been a monosyllabic, SVO syntax and isolating language. These characteristics are common among Kra-Dai and Austronesian languages. Holmer 2010 notes that the evidence for a genealogical relation between Japanese and Austronesian should not be ignored. He further states that the evidence is stronger than evidence for other proposals such as Korean or Altaic. Yoshizu Itabashi (2011) shows that similarities in morphology, phonology and basic vocabulary point towards "a strong genealogical connection between Japanese and Austronesian". He further states that: Finally, it is worth noting that Japanese and Austronesian have a common variety of prefixes, which are treated as morphology and syntax as opposed to phonology, and which are normally not borrowed, as well as the regular phonological correspondences and much common basic vocabulary. Similarly, Paul K. Benedict suggested a genetic relation between Japanese and Kra-Dai within the Austro-Tai languages, which include Kra-Dai and Austronesian. Vovin (2014) says that Benedict's idea of a genealogical relation between Japanese and Kra-Dai should not be rejected out of hand, but he considers the relationship between them not to be genetic, but rather a contact one. According to him, this contact must be quite old and quite intense, as the borrowed words belong partially to a very basic vocabulary. He further says that this evidence refutes any genetic relations between Japanese and the putative Altaic. → Japonic may have been in contact with Kra-Dai, which supports the original homeland of proto-Japonic in southern China. A short summary of proposed cognates between Kra-Dai and Japonic:  There were even some proposals which also links Koreanic with Southeast Asian languages too (such as Austronesian). This was supported by Sohn Ho-Min or Kim Nam-Kil. A Bayesian linguistic analysis (Jaeger 2015) strangely links Japonic with Austroasiatic languages such as Vietnamese and Khmer. Althought this does not prove a genealogical relation to Austroasiatic, it is in support of the known evidence and for the location of the original homeland of proto-Japonic in southern or eastern China. Elmer 2019 summarized that the most likely homeland of proto-Japonic was somewhere in southern or eastern China. A genealogical relation to local languages such as Austronesian is possible, but lacks yet conclusive evidence. The general consensus among linguists is that Japonic is one of the primary language families of the world and not directly related to another language family. Here a example for the diverse branches of the Austronesian languages on Taiwan. The Ami language: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=1CjfVLbkft0 Taiwanese Austronesian languages are suggested to be closer to the proto-Austronesian and mainland Austronesian languages. Yurayong 2020 and Kim et al. 2020 suggest that both Koreanic and Japonic are autochthonus to the Korean Peninsula and Liaoning and Shandong. Peninsular Japonic (Mumun/Yayoi) According to several historians and linguists, such as Ahn, Lee, Whitman, Janhunen, Vovin, Unger, Bellwood, and Hasegawa, Japonic languages were spoken in parts of the Korean Peninsula before they were replaced by Koreanic speakers. Whitman (2012) suggests that the proto-Koreans arrived in the southern part of the Korean Peninsula at around 300 BC and coexist with the descendants of the Japonic Mumun cultivators (and later slowly assimilated them). Both had influence on each other and a later founder effect diminished the internal variety of both language families. Japonic was brought to the Japanese archipelago by the Yayoi people already around 950 BC, during the later Jōmon period, but the massive migration of the Yayoi happened after the arrival of proto-Koreans. There is also evidence that the early Koreans borrowed words for rice cultivation from Peninsular Japonic. The middle Korean word psʌr (rice) is likely loaned from Peninsular Japonic *wasar. Some evidence for now-extinct Japonic languages in the central and southern parts of the Korean peninsula: Chapter 37 of the Samguk sagi (compiled in 1145) contains a list of pronunciations and meanings of placenames in the former kingdom of Goguryeo. As the pronunciations are given using Chinese characters, they are difficult to interpret, but several of those from central Korea, in the area south of the Han River captured from Baekje in the 5th century, seem to correspond to Japonic words but not Korean ones.The Silla placenames, listed in Chapter 34 of the Samguk sagi, are not glossed, but many of them can be explained as Japonic words.A word, explicitly attributed to the language of the Gaya confederacy, in Chapter 44 of the Samguk sagi, is a word for 'gate' and appears in a similar form to the Old Japanese word to2, with the same meaning, but is absent in Koreanic.The original name of the kingdom of Tamna on Jeju Island, tammura, may have a Japonic etymology: tani mura 'valley settlement' or tami mura 'people's settlement'.Japonic-speaking Baekje According to some linguists and historians, Baekje was still predominantly Japonic-speaking until proto-Koreans from Goguryeo or Buyeo conquered Baekje and created a Koreanic-speaking ruler class over a Japonic-speaking commoner class which was slowly koreanized. This is in accordance to the many Japonic topographical names in Baekje area. Later, Baekje spoke a Koreanic language. Additionally, Baekje had close political ties to Japan (Wa/Yamato). According to the Korean chronicle Samguk Sagi as well as the Japanese Nihon Shoki, but also Chinese chronics, Baekje sent some princes to the Japanese court as hostages. Baekje was called Kudara in Japan. Baekje also requested Japanese help after its downfall through Goguryeo forces. Japan sended military troops to Korea to aid Baekje. But after Baekjes fall, the royal Baekje family escaped from Korea to Japan and was welcomed. Thus it is likely that they still saw themselves as related people (Peninsular Japonic and Insular Japonic). General Abe no Hirafu with 20,000 troops and 1,000 ships started a mission to revive Baekje with Buyeo Pung (known in Japanese as Hōshō), a son of Uija of Baekje who had been an emissary to Japan. Around August 661, 10,000 soldiers and 170 ships, led by Abe no Hirafu, arrived. Additional Japanese reinforcement, including 27,000 soldiers led by Kamitsukeno no Kimi Wakako (上毛野君稚子) and 10,000 soldiers led by Iohara no Kimi (廬原君) also arrived at Baekje in 662. This attempt, however, failed at the Battle of Baekgang. The Japanese army retreated to Japan with the former royal family members, which were initially treated as "foreign guests" (蕃客) and were not incorporated into the political system of Japan. They adopted the name Kudara no Konikishi, also called the Kudara clan. According to Juha Janhunen, while it is well attested that Baekje was Japonic speaking, there is also evidence that Japonic languages were present in early Goguryeo and Silla. He says that the dynastical language of Goguryeo may have been a Japonic languages at first until it was replaced by Koreanic. Baekje was until its conquest predominantly Japonic speaking. Others came to similar conclusions, but some doubt that Japonic was spoken by the Goguryeo elite and instead suggest this was from loanwords adopted from Japonic Baekje. Name, etymology The term Yamato can be traced back to Old-Japanese. Yamatai-koku or Yamato-koku (邪馬台国) (c. 1st century – c. 3rd century) is the name of an ancient country in Wa (Japan) during the late Yayoi period (c. BC 300 – c. 300 AD). Modern Japanese Yamato (大和) descends from Old-Japanese Yamatö or Yamato2. It is the ethnic name for ancient Japanese. Language The Yayoi spoke a form of proto-Japonic language. The Peninsula Japonic died out and was probably assimilated into Korean. Insular Japonic evolved into Japanese and Ryukyuan. The Yamato language, known as standard Japanese and its dialects, is the only official language of Japan. In contrast, the Ainu language is linked to the ancient Jōmon languages. Possibly linked to some Native American languages. Genetics Modern Japanese have primarily Yayoi genome. Most recent estimations say that more than 90% is of Yayoi ancestry, and the less than 10% is of Jōmon ancestry for the average Japanese. Recent studies have revealed that Jomon people are considerably genetically different from any other population, including modern-day Japanese. — Takahashi et al. 2019; Adachi and Nara 2018 A more recent genetic study by Gakuhari et al. 2020 estimates only 3,3% Jōmon ancestry in average Japanese people. Japanese people are nearly completely of Yayoi descend and close to other East Asians.  About Jōmon: Jōmon people originated from Paleolithic Central Asia more than 56,000 years ago. They used the northern route through Siberia via the Altai mountain to Japan and eastern Siberia.  Jōmon people were found to be genetically unique and not closely related to any other population. Strangely they are genetically distinct from Basal-Asians and seem to be a distinct population wave which used the northern route as opposed to the southern route. They are not closely related to ancient Asian samples such as Tianyuan or Hoabhinians. (Boer et al. 2020) It was also found they share some genome with Arctic population of Eurasia. The Ainu share about 75% ancestry from the Jōmon and can be described as closest people today. Modern Japanese in contrast between ~3% to ~13%. (Note the Southern/Western and Northern/Eastern contrast.) Today there are only about 30,000 ethnic Ainu in the world. The Jōmon lineage is nearly extinct. Northern Japan (Hokkaido) which has slightly higher average Jōmon/Ainu ancestry has the lowest birth rate. It is estimated that in foreseeable future, Jōmon ancestry will further decline to non-existent. The birth rate is highest in southern and western Japan, which has nearly 100% Yayoi ancestry per average person. This will lead to a decline of the already shrinking D-lineages as well. A study concerning fertility in Japan found that carriers of D chromosome have high risk of infertility while the majority of Japanese are O chromosome carriers which have no risk at all. The cause for this remains unknown. Yayoi: Yayoi are genetically indistinguishable from other East or Southeast Asians and have the closest affinity to modern day Koreans. It is estimated that Yayoi people mainly belonged to Haplogroup O-M176 (O1b2 formerly O2b2), Haplogroup O-M122 (formerly O3 now O2) and Haplogroup O-M119 (formerly O1 now O1a), which are typical for East- and Southeast-Asians. From these, O1b2 can be linked to Japonic (Insular and Peninsular). Mitsuru Sakitani suggests that haplogroup O1b2, which is common in today Koreans, Japanese and some Manchu, and O1b1, which is most common in various Southeast Asians, are one of the carriers of the ancient Yangtze civilization. As the Yangtze civilization declined several tribes crossed westward and northerly, to the Shandong peninsula, the Korean Peninsula and the Japanese archipelago.  Insular Japonic:  Peninsular Japonic (today Korean):  We see Yayoi component influences still exist in Koreans. O1b is sometimes referred to as the Yangtzean lineage. O1b1 moved south and O1b2 moved north during very ancient times. Koreans have historical writings about the formation of Koreans through the marriage of two clans (the Yayoi and the Siberians). Tiger and Bear. Interesting: Genome Research Finds Roots of Korean Ancestry in Vietnam It is concluded that Koreans fromed from a Taiwanese/Vietnamese-linked group and Siberian-linked group. Similarly, in March 2020, a genetic study by Jungeun Kim et al. found that modern Koreans formed from a southern Chinese/Southeast Asian component and a Siberian component, which are both also closely related to each other. Ancient genome comparisons revealed that the genetic makeup of Koreans can be best described as an admixture of the Neolithic Devil’s Gate genome in Russia and the Iron Age Vat Komnou in Southeast Asia (Cambodia). About 70% of Korean genome is of southern origin and can be linked to southern Chinese and Southeast Asians, while the 30% can be linked to Northeast Asians and Siberians. See: Origin and Composition of Korean Ethnicity Analyzed by Ancient and Present-Day Genome Sequences This is in support with previous studies which links the Yayoi to southern or eastern China. Anyway, Koreans and Japanese are very closely related and genetically indistinguishable. Additionally, all East Asian, Southeast Asian, Siberian, as well as Central Asian are closely related to each other genetically. Even American Natives. It is called the Mongoloid race. Aka East-Eurasian or East Asian-related populations.   Full genome analyses reveals the distribution of Mongoloid/East-Eurasian populations.  A multiregional origin for modern humans was recently supported by studies from Yuan et al. 2019, Chen et al. 2020, Huang (various studies, most recently also in 2020). They concluded that there are three human races, Eastern-Eurasians (Mongoloids) being one of the three. They also cite and found interesting things about the MGD theory (maximum genetic diversity), neutral and non-neutral DNA and evolution as well as convergent evolution of autosomes and SNPs and “junk-DNA”. Huang notes that the three groups share probably less than 12% of total genome. Interesting, but more evidence is surely needed. Summary: Japanese are not descedants of modern ethnic Koreans. Japanese are descendants of the Japonic Yayoi/Mumun, which originated somewhere in southern or eastern China and than migrated into the Korean Peninsula in 1500BC (i.e. more than 3,500 years ago). Koreans formed from Peninsular Yayoi and Siberian tribes. Jōmon people got nearly completely replaced by the Japonic Yayoi and only the Ainu and some tribes in eastern Siberia retained Jōmon ancestry till today. The Japanese royal family is not Korean. One Japanese emperor married a royal girl from Baekje, but that does not mean the royal family is Korean. This was a really common thing in Europe too. All royal families in Europa intermarried to gain political advantages. Some aristocracy is believed to have Emishi ancestry. Additionally, several historians suggest that Baekje was Peninsular Japonic or at least multilingual between Koreanic and Peninsular Japonic. Many topographic names can be linked to Japonic but not Korean. Peninsular Japonic was get extinct and replaced by Koreanic language. It is incorrect to claim that Japanese are descendants of Koreans only because Yayoi lived in Korea. Remember that Yayoi lived there before the actual Koreans arrived. A geographical term is not a ethnic identification. I love Korea, I consider Korea the closest to Japan. Regardless of political and historical problems, we must work together. Genetically, Japanese and Korean people are indistinguishable. We are close like two brothers.🇯🇵🇰🇷🇯🇵🇰🇷  I hope this helps. If you like my answer, please upvote or comment. Thank you!

The short answer would be that the majority of population from the Japanese archipelago shared the same ancestry from the population in Korean peninsula. There’s about 85–93% gene overlap. Sorry for the long post folks but it is necessary to include the interdisciplinary studies and the arguments. Early foundation periods were called MUMUN in Korea and YAYOI in Japan and they are the same people with different labels. They’re not the only population that had the genetic influenced on Koreans and Japanese. We know much of the culture of Mumun/Yayoi was developed in the Korean peninsula. The culture is what shapes people (language, traditions, food, social standards, dress, religious beliefs, music/arts, etc). Before the Mumun/Yayoi culture, there was the Jeulmun culture (8,000 BC-1,500 BC) and is identified by the comb pattern pottery. This type of pottery was wide spread in northern Eurasia such as Finland, Russia, Siberia, Mongolia, former Manchuria and Korea. (I went to Finland to look at the pottery in the museum myself). I believe these people are Siberian and/or Tungus in origin that populated the Korean peninsula and both the Korean and Japanese population inherited the genes as the Jeulmun population naturally intermixed with Mumun/Yayoi population. Mumun culture also known for megaliths especially the Dolmens and you’ll find many across the Western and Eastern Eurasian continent but Interestingly, no Dolmens found in central and southern China. Just a note: I've been looking into this on and off for the past 2 decades and I've seen a lot of different hypotheses and theories. My lessons taught me that you don’t believe everything you read. You simply can't rely on just one disciplinary study to make any kind of conclusion such as linguistics, genetics, archaeology, bio-anthropology, ethnology, etc. Each of these disciplines provides us only one perspective. The main problem is that most of the researchers from one discipline work independently and not collaboratively with other fields. It needs to be a multidisciplinary observation to get a full picture. It's like doing a detective work as much of our past history has not been documented. The interpretations and theories can vary widely from time to time in genetic science, archaeology, linguistic and history are constantly evolving and therefore people should use words like “possibly”, “assumably”, “likely” when we’re stating undocumented events. The genetic revolution has only started 15 years ago and we’ll be learning more about it in the near future as new theories are being developed and updated. GeographyGeography is a great deal, there’s more convenience to everything if you’re closer. It’s only 110 miles from Korea to Japan. You can easily travel the distance in a day. Every culture in human history were influenced by cultures nearby. GeneticKoreans and Japanese inherited the Northeastern and Southeastern asian genes long before Mumun/Yayoi period. O1b2 (formerly O2b1) is considered a determinate haplogroup marker for Mumun/Yayoi. One certain thing is that ancient population of Mumun/Yayoi were the main contributors to both Koreans and Japanese gene pool. Both populations have the similar distribution of O1b2 haplogroup marker (30-35%) and that no other population has except for Manchurians (10%). It’s basically a Northeastern Asian marker “most likely” originated in Manchuria/Liaoning regions. The genetic distance between O1b2 (Northeast Asia—Korean, Japanese and Manchu) and O1b1 (Southeast Asia—Southern Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai, Laos, Eastern India) is about 25,000 to 32,000 years. I don’t considered that as being closely related considering that Caucasoid and Mongoloid split around 40,000 years ago. Below are the maps of O1b2 and O1b1 distribution. Most of O1b2 are concentrated mainly in Korea and Japan. O1b1 in Southeast Asia, South China and East India.   ~90% of Korean and Japanese genes overlap and it can be indistinguishable.  The bar graph indicates the proportion of continental Asian clusters contributing to a given Japanese cluster. Hondo (main Japanese island population) and Ryukyu.  In 1999, I came across a study from collaboration of Satoshi Yamaguchi and the Chinese researchers where they’re making a direct connection to southern China/Yangtze area to the origin of Yayoi, BUT only to find out that it wasn’t a multidisciplinary studies. This theory has never gained much of acceptance by respected eastern and western scholars as there’s no archaeological findings and lack of genetic evidence (it was mainly based on a single rice grain that they didn’t find in Korean peninsula, and 3 out 36 skulls and limbs “resembling” to Yayoi but NO statement about the specific genetic details). You can easily find 3 out of 36 skeletons “resembling” Yayoi in the Hunnic or Avar cemetary in Hungary and Romania. Many viewed this research as being politically motivated because that was the time when the Japanese and the Chinese governments are trying to mend on trade and political issues. This is a lot like saying that the British are descendants from Anatolian (now Turkey) farmers or Middle-easterners by spreading agriculture to Europe. You simply can not make a DIRECT connection that occurred 9000 years ago. Serious flaws with Yangtze origin theoryThis will remain problematic, until it can adequately explain a number of crucial issues: Most of the scholars agree that the wet rice farming started by the proto-Austronesian near the Yangtze delta area roughly 9,000-10,000 years ago and spread to north and south. 1) No matching O1b2 signature marker that represents Mumun/Yayoi population 2) Why the paddy field cultivation first appeared in the Hakata and Karatsu Bays-areas of northern Kyushu that are points in the archipelago closest to southern Korea-rather than along the southwest coastal region of Kyushu facing the East China Sea 3) Why only the short-grain Japonica type, adapted to cool climate and grown in Korea, first appeared in northern Kyushu when both Japonica and the long-grain indica types were grown in the Yangtze River basin 4) Why grooved adzes, triangular reaping knives, polished stone daggers, pottery vessels, settlement patterns, and mortuary practices closely associated with the early Yayoi farming communities are found only in southern Korea but not in the Yangtze River basin 5) Why the initial paddy rice agriculture in Japan exemplified a whole complex identifiable with Mumun Korea’s cultural system rather than that of the lower Yangtze River basin 6) No dolmens were found in Yangtze area which associated with Mumun culture (Jeon 1986:107-117; Takakura 1995:283-288; Tanaka 1997:102). Other main problem is that there’s no Yangtze related artifacts found in Japan per Mark Hudson (leading archaeologist in Japan). ArchaeologyOne of the most important area to look into is a field of archaeology as it will provide a concrete physical evidences more so than linguistic, history or even genetic. I most likely dismiss any theories without being accompanied by archaeological evidences. Much of the findings are identical and consistent in both Korea and Japan.  Mumun stone dagger. Korea (left). LanguageLinguistics academic discipline has the most ongoing controversial and wild hypotheses compare to all other disciplines. Many of them are short-lived or dismissed in a few years. This has been the most contentious and mysterious issues between the Korean and Japanese languages. The cognates are different but the grammar is almost identical as you can translate word for word. This is the main reason why much of the opinions are divided among the scholars making the genetic connections. The Chinese/Sino-Tibetan is a tonal language. The cognates or grammars are immensely different (besides loan words). It’s classified as a different language family. You can basically say that the Korean or Japanese are more related to Uralic and Altaic than to Sino-Tibetan. The Japonic language (1500 BC) There’s some serious confusion regarding the word Japonic. Japonic is a linguistic term and NOT the people. Linguists named it Japonic because it is only now spoken in Japan and can be misleading because it has the origin in western part of Liaoning/Manchuria and spoken in Korean peninsula at the time of Mumun and Yayoi. They’re mainly agriculturalists. The Koreanic language (300-500 BC) Korean bronze/iron dagger culture and equestrians) As I’ve stated above for Japonic, Koreanic is also a linguistic term and NOT the people. I speculate that the Koreanic speakers were from Gojoseon kingdom (Northern Korea, Manchuria/Liaoning) before the successor of 3 kingdoms (Baekje, Goguryeo and Silla). The timeline fits within the settlement of Koreanic speakers in the southern peninsula with many archaeological findings and eventually replacing the Japonic language but NOT the people of Mumun/Yayoi culture. Many Mumun/Yayoi from the Korean peninsula emigrated to Japan where they eventually became the majority in Japan but much more stayed in Korean peninsula (you won’t see an entire population moving to an island on ships) and eventually intermingled with the Koreanic speakers (Koreanic speaking population was smaller than the Mumun/Yayoi Japonic speakers in Korea). Mumun/Yayoi lived in the Korean peninsula since 1500BC which was at least 1000 years longer. One interesting to note is that there were no horses during the Mumun/Yayoi period in Korea and Japan. It’s believed that the Koreanic/bronze and iron dagger culture people introduced the horses. Goguryeo, Baekje and Silla (3 kingdoms in Korea) known to spoke Koreanic along with substrate Japonic . Both Baekje and Goguryeo came from the same group of people from Buyeo in Manchuria. The older Jin state (southern Korea) before the 3 kingdoms “probably” spoke Japonic. Wet rice cultivationThe spread of millets and rice into Japan is dated to the beginning of the first millennium BC, marking the beginning of the Yayoi period (900BC– 300AD). It is associated with an influx of farmers from the Korean peninsula who brought the Japonic language to Japan. Apart from rice, millets and various crops, Northeast Asian influences include pottery, stone and wooden agricultural tools, domesticated pigs, ditched settlements and megalith burials. It is clear that agriculture arrived in Japan as a “package” of Northeast Asian culture, even if this package had a southern, Austronesian-like touch.  Shandong/Liaodong dispersion hypothesis of wet rice farming Miyamoto presents a scenario where agriculture spread from (possibly distinct) locations in northeast China to the east and north. Miyamoto distinguishes three major spreads of agriculture from this region. The first, associated with Setaria and Panicum, spreads from the Liaoning region to the northwestern part of the Korean peninsula and thence to its eastern and southern coasts. Miyamoto’s scenario for the dispersion is consistent with the scenario for the introduction of wet rice cultivation into the Korean peninsula provided by Ahn. Ahn argues against earlier views that wet rice cultivation was introduced into the Korean peninsula from the south, and concludes in favor of the scenario where it enters the peninsula from Liaodong in the early Mumun period around or after 1500 BCE. Thereafter, evidence for agricultural settlements engaged in rice farming is found throughout the peninsula with the exception of the northeast. Northeast Asian Linguistic Ecology and the Advent of Rice Agriculture in Korea and Japan There has been a new research by the Chinese researcher, Fu recently that the northern China’s Yellow River area holding the clue to the direct spread of rice and millet farming to Liaoning and Korean peninsula. Goguryeo, Baekje and Silla (3 kingdoms in Korea) Kofun (Japan) eraI’ve spent more time researching on this portion of the history. Another major waves of migration took place is during the middle Kofun era. We still don’t know whether this was a peaceful migration or invasion by Baekje and Gaya. To make it short, the invasion theory has some merit due to the sudden findings of Baekje and Gaya relics (horses, horse trappings, armors, military related equipment) in many of the middle Kofun era tombs. It is widely known that the Gaya and Baekje had the most material, technology, cultural and political influences on Japan. This has been proven by both countries and therefore I don’t need to say “probably”. This happened when tumultuous events were unfolding in the Korean peninsula. In return, Goguryeo forces dealt a devastating blow to Gaya for supporting Baekje and later killed the Baekje King. The devastating warfare continued on and at various points, many people of Gaya and Baekje fled, sailing to Japanese archipelago. Gaya immigrants were responsible for the development of iron industries in Japan. Baekje was even greater and more critical to cultural and sociopolitical transformation in Kofun Japan. Baekje citizens migrated to Kyoto-Osaka-Nara region by 400 AD. There they engaged in Sue pottery and also undertook the first large scale canal and dam projects to drain Kawachi wetland for agricultural expansion, critical to the growing Yamato power. Many western and eastern archaeologists and historians long have speculated that the Yamato ruling clan had a direct lineage to Baekje royalties and not just the maternal line of Emperor Kammu. Fwiw, I consider myself 100% Korean as both my parents and grandparents on both sides, and all their ancestors hail from Korea, and in terms of ethnic identity and nationality, never considered themselves anything else but. That said, when historians describe pre-modern migratory patterns, they usually describe them in terms of migratory waves or a wave of migration. I think this is an apt metaphor and about as accurate as you can get in describing how human populations in Asia migrated from one end of the continent to the other, eventually settling down, and begin to people their countries. On the otherhand, the concept of a melting pot of different races and ethnicities converging together and mixing en masse to create large populations of racial and/or ethnic admixtures, does not accurately describe Asia’s pre-modern migrations. Why? Because the melting pot theory is a manifestation of the modern era where large-scale migrations of people occurred over long distances and across natural barriers, like oceans, mountain chains, wide expanses of arid land, etc., all occurring in a fraction of the time it took during pre-modern times. These modern mass migrations, influenced typically by social upheaval, colonization, war, epic transitions in society, famine, pestilence, etc., were made possible because of the development of groudbreaking technologies, e.g., large-capacity ships, steamships, jet airliners, cars & trains — all modes of transportation that did not exist until a couple of centuries ago. When examining the case of migratory patterns in East Asia, however, just think about a wave of migration spanning thousands and thousands of years back when a landbridge existed between Korea and Japan. And just like vehicles on a high-speed interstate highway, thousands upon thousands of migratory waves passed through these established migratory routes until they could go no further. Some waves washed ashore, some waves broke before they ever hit the shore. But by and large, the waves kept on coming and going, moving further out until they could move no further. And where those waves finally broke and settled, we can only surmise that’s where Japan is and who the Japanese people are today representing a convergence zone if you will, of inter-asian migratory waves coming from all points of Asia — not just from Korea. Then there are situations like war and other calamitous events over the millenia and centuries like famine, political upheavals, etc, that caused entire dynasties to uproot seeking refuge or asylum elsewhere. This happened to Korea at the tail end of Korea’s Three Kingdom Era (삼국시대) when Silla absorbed the neighboring Korean states of Baekche, Goryeo, and Gaya at the end of the 8th Century. In the case of Baekche and Gaya, many remnants of those displaced dynasties flooded over in successive waves of migration into Japan, especially in areas like Nara where remnants of the Gaya people introduced their arts & culture, e.g., the 12-string Gayageum (가야금) to the locals which became the precursor to the Japanese Koto. In light of that, people should view the formation of cultures and ethnic groups in Asia as proceeding along a much longer timeline and slower wave-like pattern compared to the mosaic of people and cultures found in the melting pots of the West.

Here’s something that Japanese nationalists don’t like to see. This is a chart of the genetic composition of Han Chinese people from different provinces, based on data from 23Mofang. The Japanese component (日本, third column to the right) reaches its zenith among Liaoning people (Liaoning being a province in Northeast China bordering North Korea), and it slowly decreases as one moves to the south. In the Far South of China (Guangdong and Guangxi) where the Zhuang-Dai or Kra-Dai (壮傣, sixth column to the right) component reaches its zenith, Japanese component is actually 0%. In the Southwest province of Yunnan, Japanese component is also 0%. If the Japanese are really related to Austronesian or Kra-Dai or other southern peoples like some Japanese posters here seems to suggest, then we should expect to see the 日本 component increasing and not decreasing as one moves to the south of China. The fact that Japanese component reaches its zenith in the Northeast province of Liaoning and is absent in the Far South of China is a strong indication to me that at least genetically speaking, the Japanese aren’t closely related to the southern Asians.  Population autosomal PCA charts have revealed similar results that Japanese are quite distant from southern Asians. Like this PCA chart from 23Mofang the blue Japanese cluster is positioned on the top right corner, while the Dai cluster is located on the bottom right corner.  And if people still aren’t convinced, here’s the World G25 Calculator, we can see the Japanese and Koreans only scored 5.8% and 5.2% TWN_Hanben (Neolithic Taiwan Austronesian) respectively, which is lower than many other East Asian populations. On the other hand, they scored 21.8% and 19% Devil’s Gate respectively, which is only lower than North Asian Buryat but higher than all other East Asian populations.  Archaeologically speaking, there’s also nothing that links Japan to the Far South of China. It’s pretty evident now that the Yayoi people had a strong connection to the Mumun culture of Korea. Some people might use rice cultivation as a counter-argument, but guess what? Rice cultivation had actually begun in Central / Eastern China around 8,200 years ago, not the Far South of China. Contrary to popular misconception, Far South China and Southwest China were on the receiving end of the spread of agriculture. Rice cultivation only reached there around 4,000 years ago, which is rather late. By that time Northern China or possibly even Korea already had rice cultivation. And for those who don’t know, Northeast China is actually one of the largest rice producing regions in China. Linguistically, I know that a few scholars have proposed some fringe theories about the origin of Japonic and Koreanic families, linking them to Tamil, Austronesian, Kra-Dai, or Austroasiatic. But rest assured that those theories aren’t widely accepted in the academic circles. The mainstream view is that Japonic is an isolate family comprised of just Japanese and Ryukyuan. And also, even if Japanese indeed borrowed a few words from southern languages, that doesn’t mean Japanese people originated from the south. Linguistics and genetics are completely different matters and people shouldn’t confound one with the other. To give a relevant example, Mandarin has borrowed words from English, but that doesn’t mean Chinese people and British people are closely related genetically. Overall, I fail to see how Japanese are closely related to southern Asians. The insistence of certain Japanese nationalists on a southern origin of the Japanese is, for me at least, more likely to have ulterior political motives.

Almost exactly half of Japanese men belong to haplogroup O, a paternal lineage of Paleolithic Sino-Korean origin that is now found all over East and Southeast Asia. Haplogroup O3 (aka O-M122) is the main Han Chinese paternal lineage. It is an extremely diverse lineage, with numerous subclades, including many associated with the expansion of agriculture from northern China. Most of them are found in Korea and would have been part of the Yayoi migration to Japan. However, some specific subclades, notably O3a1c (JST002611) and O3a2 (P201) are considerably more common in southern China and among non-aboriginal Taiwanese (25%) than in Korea (6%). Within Japan, it reaches a maximum frequency in Okinawa (16%), a region with low Yayoi ancestry. Its frequency among non-Okinawan Japanese is of 10-15%, about twice higher than in Korea, a fact that cannot be explained by the Yayoi invasion. O3a1c and O3a2 could have come to Japan during the Jomon period with Neolithic farmers from southern China associated with the Austronesian expansion via Taiwan (see below).
